items.title: Old caves yield new secrets from Canadians who went over the top at Vimy Ridge
items.description: A hidden archive of what for many were last thoughts and tributes to Canada is emerging from the soft chalk tunnels beneath the Vimy Ridge battlefield more than a century after they were created.

items.title: Canada could face ‘worst kind’ of flu season as experts warn evolving strain may be mismatch for vaccine
items.description: With flu cases now rising in Canada, medical experts are bracing for a difficult influenza season linked to the global spread of an evolving H3N2 strain that could be a mismatch for this year’s vaccine.

items.title: What’s in the federal budget for you? Your questions answered
items.description: Many Canadians wrote to us asking what they should be looking for in the new federal budget. CBC News’ Catherine Cullen and J.P. Tasker are here to help break down what is – and isn’t – in the budget.

items.title: Manitoba Government Honours Indigenous Veterans and Supports First-Annual Powwow
After fuel spill in B.C. lake, early tests show no contamination above drinking water guidelines
items.description: B.C. officials say that preliminary tests show no contamination above drinking water guidelines after 80,000 litres of fuel was spilled into Kamloops Lake following a train derailment.

items.title: Canadians honour Indigenous veterans with ceremonies across the country
items.description: Canadians marked Indigenous Veterans Day with ceremonies countrywide, honouring First Nations, Inuit and Métis service members and calling for continued reconciliation.

items.title: How the woman who wasn't allowed to play built a future for Canadian hockey
items.description: Danièle Sauvageau, the girl who grew up in Deux-Montanges, Que., and wasn’t allowed to play on an organized hockey team because she wasn’t a boy, is now the first woman 'Builder' inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame.

items.title: Accessibility is coming to playgrounds in Regina
items.description: Sarah Turnbull isn't just a city councillor, but also a mother, and she's looking to make a change when it comes to accessible parks in Regina.

items.title: More Montreal transit staff to strike, but walkout not expected to disrupt service
items.description: A third union at Montreal’s transit network will hold a one-day strike Nov. 19, joining other groups in disputes over subcontracting, job security, and stalled negotiations.

items.title: Canadian travellers to Europe face new border measures as security ramps up
items.description: Canadians heading to Europe will soon need new travel clearance as EU officials roll out biometric checks and a €20 ETIAS pass next year.

items.title: Advocates concerned temporary immigration cuts don't address systemic issues
Vancouver Rise advance to inaugural Northern Super League final after shootout win over Rapid
items.description: The Vancouver Rise are heading to the inaugural Northern Super League final after defeating the Ottawa Rapid in a shootout Saturday.

items.title: How one North Vancouver school is redefining education for neurodiverse learners in B.C.
Nield thrilled to help gambling Riders beat Lions
items.description: Touchdown Tommy Nield is going to the Grey Cup again -- and this time he's taking the Saskatchewan Roughriders with him.

items.title: Roughriders off to Grey Cup after beating Lions
items.description: Tommy Nield's three-yard touchdown reception with 11 seconds left in the fourth quarter lifted the Saskatchewan Roughriders to a 24-21 victory over the B.C. Lions in the West Division final Saturday, sending the Riders to the Grey Cup.

items.title: Riders score late TD to down Lions, punch ticket to Grey Cup
items.description: The Saskatchewan defence forced back-to-back two-and-out possessions to give their offence an opportunity to win the game.
